instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the deep neural network models in recognizing multiple types of oral cancer tissues and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the deep neural network models in this study is the overall accuracy rate, precision rate, and recall rate. The overall accuracy rate measures the percentage of correctly classified samples out of the total number of samples. The overall precision rate measures the percentage of true positive samples out of all the samples predicted as positive, while the overall recall rate measures the percentage of true positive samples out of all the actual positive samples.

The overall accuracy rate of the best-performing model, ResNet50, was reported to be 92.81%. This means that the model correctly classified 92.81% of the oral cancer tissue and normal tissue samples.

instruction: How were the existing classical deep neural network models used to recognize multiple types of oral cancer tissues in the study?
Output: In the study, the existing classical deep neural network models (AlexNet, VGGNet, ResNet50, MobileNetV2, Transformer) were used to recognize multiple types of oral cancer tissues. To achieve this, 16,200 Raman spectra were collected from 180 tissue samples of 90 patients who had undergone surgical resection due to tongue squamous cell carcinoma, gingival squamous cell carcinoma, and buccal squamous cell carcinoma. These models were then trained and predicted at the patient level. The performance of each model was evaluated based on overall accuracy rate, overall precision rate, and overall recall rate. The experimental results showed that ResNet50 had the best performance in identifying oral cancer tissue and normal tissue, with an overall accuracy rate of 92.81%, an overall precision rate of 92.93%, and an overall recall rate of 92.86%.
